questions.question: A patient comes with long-standing non-pitting edema in the legs. What is the most probablecause?

A patient comes to you with complaints of long-standing swelling of the left leg, as shown inthe image. The swelling disappears in the morning and on examination, pitting is seen. Whatgrade of lymphedema is this?
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, pitting edema which disappears completely on elevation and bedrest indicates grade I lymphedema, according to Brunner's classification.Skin changes seen in lymphedema include peau d'orange, erythema, hyperkeratosis, ulceration,stemmer sign, and buffalo hump.Stemmer sign is the inability to pinch a fold of skin on the dorsum of the toes due tolymphedema.Clinical classification of lymphedema:Grade (Brunner)Clinical featuresSubclinicalGrade IGrade IIGrade IIIThere is excessive interstitialfluid and histological abnormalities in lymphatics and lymph nodes, but no clinically apparent lymphedema.Edema pits on pressure and the swelling completely disappears on elevation and bed rest.Edema does not pit and doesnot significantly reduce on elevationEdema is associated with irreversible skin changes, i.e. fibrosis and papillae.

questions.question: While examining a patient with lymphoedema, you are unable to pinch the skin of the patienton the base of the toes. What is this sign called?
questions.explanation: In lymphedema, skin on the base of the toes cannot be pinched due to subcutaneous fibrosis. Thissign is called Stemmer's sign.SignStemmer's signDescriptionSeen in lymphoedemaskin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched due to Subcutaneous Fibrosis.1235SignFrank's signDescriptionA diagonal crease in the earlobe that runs backward from the tragus at a 45-degree angle across the lobule to the rearedge of the auricle. May be apredictor of coronary arterydisease.Levine's signClenched fist held over the chest to describe ischemic chestpain.Winterbottom's signPosterior cervical lymphadenopathy in african trypanosomiasis.

questions.question: Which of the following will you perform when asked to do a lymphangiography of the leg?1230

options.A: Inject sodium diatrizoate subcutaneously on the dorsum of the foot
options.B: Inject sodium diatrizoate retrogradely under pressure into a small vein on the dorsum of foot
options.C: Dissect the lymphatics through an incision on the dorsum of foot and injecting contrast
options.D: Insertion of guidewire into the lymphatic system of the leg and inject contrast

questions.explanation: 1236Direct contrast lymphangiography is done by dissecting the lymphatic vasculature through anincision on the dorsum of the foot and injecting contrast.Direct contrast lymphangiography is an invasive study done to visualise the lymphatic system. Itinvolves exposure and cannulation of lymphatics and slow injection of contrast medium suchas ethiodized oil.Complications:• Damage to the visualized lymphatics•Allergic reactions• Pulmonary embolism if the oil-based contrast agent enters the venous system throughlymphovenous anastomosis.Contrast magnetic resonance lymphangiography is a newer testing method. It is performed afterintracutaneous injection of gadobenate dimeglumine into the interdigital webs of the dorsal foot.It is capable of visualizing the anatomy and functional status of lymph flow transport of lymphaticvessels and lymph nodes of lymphedematous limbs.B0Image A shows a lymphangiography with normal uptake.Image B shows a lymphangiography scan with no uptake in Milroy's disease.Image C depicts a lymphangiography scan in a patient with lymphoedema and reflux.

questions.question: Which of the following complications are least likely to develop, in patients with chroniclymphoedema?
questions.explanation: Marjolin's ulcers are unlikely to develop in patients with chronic lymphedema.Marjolin's ulcers are malignant ulcers that develop over chronic scars, most commonly fromburns. Marjolin's ulcer may also develop in chronic long standing venous ulcers but are not seenin chronic lymphedema.1237Initially, the lymphedema is soft and pits on the pressure but with time the skin becomesthickened and non-pitting due to fibrosis, dermal thickening, and hyperkeratosis.Frequent episodes of lymphangitis and cellulitis may occur. This is due to loss of local immunedefense mechanisms. Chronic eczema, the fungal infection of skin and nails, fissuring, verrucae,and papillae (warts) are frequently seen in advanced disease.Rarely malignancy (lymphangiosarcoma or angiosarcoma) may occur in chronic lymphedema.This neoplastic transformation of blood vessels and lymphatics is called Stewart-Treves syndrome.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding mediastinal lymphoma is false?

options.A: Middle mediastinum is the most common site of mediastinal lymphoma
options.C: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice
options.D: Video assisted thoracoscopy is used to diagnose the condition

questions.explanation: Anterior compartment is the most common site of lymphoma in the mediastinum. Other sitesinclude the middle compartment and hilar nodes.Primary mediastinal lymphoma is an uncommon type of lymphoma. Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL),primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma (PMBCL), and T-lymphoblastic lymphoma are the mostcommon primary mediastinal lymphomas. In about 50% of patients who have both Hodgkin's andNon-Hodgkin's Lymphoma, the mediastinum may be the primary site.Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome refers to symptoms produced by the obstruction of blood flowthrough the SVC by the enlarging mediastinal mass, resulting in symptoms of dyspnea, facial andupper-extremity edema, cough, chest pain, and dysphagia.Video-assisted thoracoscopy (VATS) is used to obtain a biopsy of the mediastinal mass forconfirmation and diagnosis.Chemotherapy with six cycles of R-CHOP regimen is preferred. Rituximab is a chimericmonoclonal anti-CD20 antibody and has become a standard component of treating all B-celllymphoma histologies that express CD20.Note: Thymoma is the most common mediastinal tumor in adults (overall).

options.B: It is a congenital sequestration of lymphatic channelLaser excision is doned) Sclerotherapy is not used in treatmentQuestion 9:Where is lymphangiosarcoma most commonly seen?a) Cystic hygromab) Milroy disease

questions.explanation: The given image depicts a lymphangioma, also known as cystic hygroma. They are brilliantlytransilluminant.Lymphangiomas are congenital benign tumors of the lymphatic system. They are the isolatedcystic mass of lymphatic tissue that has the ability to produce lymph. Over time the tumorenlarges due to the accumulation of lymph within the cyst.Types of lymphangiomas:Simple or capillary lymphangioma: They occur subcutaneously in the head, neck, and axilla.They may also occur within the internal organs and connective tissues in the thoracic andabdominal cavities.• Cavernous lymphangioma or cystic hygroma: They also occur in the neck or axilla. Rarely theymay occur in retroperitoneum.1238Treatment includes surgical excision of the tumor and image-guided sclerotherapy.If there is any residual lymphatic malformation after the treatment, then a conservative excisionor unroofing of the cyst is done. It may be combined with sclerosing therapy or repeated partialexcisions.Note: The terms lymphangioma and cystic hygromas are older terms. They are now calledlymphatic malformations.

questions.question: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swellinginvolving the arm as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?1232
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedemainvolving the upper limb.Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. Itis a common complication of breast cancer treatment involving axillary lymph nodedissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of1239lymphedema significantly.Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in the limbsize due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limbfatigue, and reduced limb mobility.Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm>2 centimeters than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% orgreater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria.Management:Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices can help reduceswelling.Dry skin can be seen due to fluid accumulation, which can lead to cellulitis/skin infections. Usinga low pH water-based moisturizer is helpful.Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) bythe patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation.Benzpyrones and flavonoids are some naturally occurring substances that may be of use to treatlymphedema.Surgical options are lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking.Other options:Option B: Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standinglymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiplebluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage.Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorousexercise and in weightlifters. The subclavian vein is compressed at the thoracic outlet. Painfulswelling of the arm is observed.Option D: Cellulitis usually presents with an ulcer and the skin is erythematous, swollen, andpainful. Fever, chills, and rigor follow.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of decongestive lymphoedema therapy (DLT)?
questions.explanation: Diuretics and Homan's procedure are not a part of DLT, and are a part of drug therapy andsurgical management.Decongestive lymphoedema therapy (DLT) is the currently used method for controlling swelling inlymphoedema. It consists of 2 phases: intensive and maintenance.Intensive phase includes:• Skin care: Prevent drying of skin and exposure to the sun, avoid venipuncture from the affectedlimb.•• Limb elevation• Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) - Proximal massage along lymphatic channels.1240• Compression therapy: Multilayer lymphoedema bandaging (MLLB), Pneumatic lymphoedemastockings, Graded compression stockings (100% in the ankle/foot, 70% in the knee, 50% inmid-thigh, and 40% in the groin).•Exercise: Slow rhythmic isotonic movements are beneficial, while vigorous, anaerobic isometricexercises are to be avoided.Standard MLLB is only done if ABPI is 0.8. It is contraindicated if ABPI is < 0.5.Maintenance phase includes:•Simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) - It is a simple massage technique done by the patient.• Pain relief

questions.question: Which among the following is not a limb reduction surgery for lymphoedema?
questions.explanation: Kinmonth procedure is a bypass surgery done for lymphoedema not a limb reduction surgery.Surgical management of lymphoedema is divided into bypass procedures, liposuction, and limbreduction procedures.• Bypass procedures include:• Neilubowicz procedure - anastomosing lymph nodes to the veins.•⚫ Kinmonth procedure - using ileal mucosal patch.•• Limb reduction procedures include:• Sistrunk procedure - A wedge of skin and subcutaneous tissue is excised and the wound closedprimarily. This is the most commonly carried out procedure to reduce the girth of the thigh.•Homan's procedure - Skin flaps are raised, and then subcutaneous tissue is excised from beneaththe flaps.• Thompson's procedure - Modification of Homan's procedure.• Charles procedure - Excision of all of the skin and subcutaneous tissues down to the deep fascia,with coverage using split-skin grafts.1241
